results.question: How is the fair value of financial instruments that are not traded in active markets determined?
results.markdown_table_response: Fair value is determined by using the following valuation techniques: • Dealer quotes for similar instruments • The fair value of interest rate swaps is calculated as the present value of the estimated future cash flows based on observable yield curves; and • Other techniques, such as discounted cash flow analysis, are used to determine fair value for financial instruments.

The fair value of financial instruments that are not traded in active markets is determined by using valuation techniques. gold_answer: on the date of his or her initial appointment to the Board of Directors equal to the pro-rated amount of the annual grant
results.markdown_table_response:
To receive an option grant, a non-employee director must receive an option grant equal to the fair value of the stock awarded to the director, measured in accordance with ASC 718, excluding the effect of estimated forfeitures, which is equal to the fair value of the option granted to the director at the time the option grant is made. If a non-employee director is initially appointed after any annual meeting of stockholders, he or she may receive a restricted stock unit award or option grant equal to the fair value of the stock awarded to the director, measured in accordance with ASC 718, excluding the effect of estimated forfeitures, equal to the fair value of the option granted to the director at the time of the initial appointment. The option granted to the director is exercisable after the tenth anniversary of the date of grant or the next annual meeting of stockholders. The option grant is exercisable on the date of the option grant, or the next annual meeting of stockholders, if the option grant is exercisable during the period of the option grant.
The option grant is exercisable in the first year following the date of grant. The option grant may be exercisable after the termination of the director’s services as described in the option agreement

results.question: How is Basic earnings per share, or EPS calculated?
gold_answer: by dividing net income (loss) by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period, without consideration for common stock equivalents.
results.markdown_table_response:
Basic earnings per share, or EPS, is calculated by dividing net income (loss) by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period without consideration for common stock equivalents. Dilutive common stock equivalents are excluded from the calculation of diluted EPS when their effect is dilutive. In periods in which the Company has a net loss, dilutive common stock equivalents are excluded from the calculation of diluted EPS. The numerator is calculated by dividing net income (loss) by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period. The denominator is calculated by dividing the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period without consideration for common stock equivalents. Dilutive common stock equivalents are excluded from the calculation of diluted EPS when their effect is dilutive. In periods in which the Company has a net loss, dilutive common stock equivalents are excluded from the calculation of diluted EPS.

results.question: What is the % change in the capital intensity ratio for BCE?
results.markdown_table_response:
BCE capital expenditures totaled $3,988  million for the year, up $17 million over 2018. Capital spending in the year reflected the following:
• Greater capital investments in our wireless segment of $33 million in 2019, compared to 2018, as we advanced the build-out of our LTE-A network, continued to deploy wireless small-cells to expand capacity to support subscriber growth and increase network speeds, coverage and signal quality, as well as to expand data fibre backhaul in preparation for 5G technology
• A modest reduction in capital spending in our wireline segment of $10 million in 2019, compared to last year, as we continued to focus our investments on the ongoing deployment of FTTP to more homes and businesses, the roll-out of fixed WTTP to rural locations in Ontario and Québec, the connection of fibre Internet and TV services to more homes and businesses and the execution of business customer contracts
• Lower capital expenditures at Bell Media of $6 million in 2019, compared to last year, mainly due to production equipment and IT upgrades in 2018
results.csv_string_response:
The capital intensity ratio for BCE is
$$
\frac{C_{10} \times A_{10} \times P_{10} \times F_{10} \times T_{10}}{C_{10} \times A_{10} \times P_{10} \times F_{10} \times T_{10}}
$$
where $C_{10}$ is the capital intensity ratio of 10 dBm; $A_{10}$ is the 10 dBm power density; $P_{10}$ is the 10 dBm peak-to-average power density; $F_{10}$ is the peak-to-average power density; $T_{10}$ is the 10 dBm peak-to-average time-varying brightness; and $P_{10}$ is the 10 dBm peak-to-average power density.
results.json_rows_response: For the year, capital spending in the BCE segment was $3,988 million, up $17 million compared to 2018.

• A modest reduction in capital spending in our wireline segment of $10 million in 2019, compared to last year, as we continued to focus our investments on the ongoing deployment of FTTP to more homes and businesses, the roll-out of fixed WTTP to rural locations in Ontario and Québec, the connection of fibre Internet and TV services to more homes and businesses and the execution of business customer contracts
• Lower capital expenditures at Bell Media of $6 million in 2019, compared to last year, mainly due to production equipment and IT upgrades in 2018

• Greater capital investments in our wireless segment of $33 million in 2019, compared to 2018, as we advanced the build-out of our LTE-A network, continued to deploy wireless small-cells to expand capacity to support subscriber growth and increase network speeds, coverage and signal quality, as well as to expand data fibre backhaul in preparation for 5G technology
• A modest reduction in capital expenditures in our wireline segment of $10 million in 2019, compared to last year, as we continued to focus our investments on the ongoing deployment of FTTP to more homes and businesses, the roll-out of fixed WTTP to rural locations in Ontario and Québec, the connection of fibre Internet and TV services to more homes and businesses and the execution of business customer contracts
• Lower capital expenditures at Bell Media of $6 million in 2019, compared to last year, mainly due to production equipment and IT upgrades in 2018
